VideoTitle: Tip 1: Async void is for top-level event-handlers only
Author: Charles
Description: Async Tip #1: Async void is for top-level event-handlers only, and event-like things. Don't use it elsewhere in your code. Slides are available on Lucian's blog. Async void is a "fire-and-forget&

VideoTitle: Tip 2: Distinguish CPU-Bound work from IO-bound work
Author: Charles
Description: Async Tip #2: It's crucial to distinguish CPU-bound work (should be done on threadpool) from IO-bound work (which needn't). You can download slides for this talk from Lucian's blog. I remember reading

VideoTitle: Tip 3: Wrap events up in Task-returning APIs and await them
Author: Charles
Description: Async Tip #3: You can wrap events up in Task-returning APIs and await them. This can dramatically simplify code. Slides and source code are available on Lucian's blog. This video introduces a new patt

VideoTitle: Tip 4: Async Library Methods Shouldn't Lie
Author: Lucian Wischik
Description: Libraries shouldn't lie. That's not why they're called "lie-braries"... The threadpool is an app-global resource, so you should leave the callers of your library to decide how and when they

VideoTitle: Tip 5: Async libraries APIs should be chunky
Author: Lucian Wischik
Description: 5. Libraries should have chunky async APIs. But if you can't achieve that, there's a micro-optimization you can use for async methods based around the fast-path which can reduce or eliminate the heap

VideoTitle: Tip 6: Async library methods should consider using Task.ConfigureAwait(false)
Author: Lucian Wischik
Description: 6. Libraries should consider Task.ConfigureAwait(false). This is another micro-optimization you can use to reduce your methods' impact on the UI thread. Consider this if your library routine might be
